user_request: A poem where the speaker hears America singing, each worker their own song.
final_poem:
# Hear America Singing

Hear the truck driver humming near the median,
finger pressing circles on the steering column's chrome,
singing a tune he learned in Texas
with his window cracked so the wind could carry it.

Hear the nurse at four AM, chart in hand,
whispering to her shift: *I'm here. I'm here again.*
Her shoes click hollow down the linoleum,
each step a verse she writes on patient floors.

Hear the nail technician in South Florida
chatting with a customer about Netflix—
her hands work faster than any mouth,
painting cuticles into rainbows nobody will see.

Hear the border patrol agent eating lunch
in his unmarked sedan, watching nothing,
holding a sandwich that tastes like duty
tastes like every day he doesn't have to name.

Hear the student with two jobs, studying
between shifts at the pharmacy counter—
her textbook open to page three hundred and fourteen,
the lullaby of fluorescent lights underneath her finger tips.

Each one singing what comes easy: *I'm here.*
The layout technician in Memphis sends files off-peak,
fingers dancing over keys that press against his sternum like old friends.
He sings in the quiet between transmissions, no one tuning in but him.

Hear them all—ten thousand humming bees
at different pitches, different volumes, different octaves of staying.
They don't know their songs overlap. They don't need to.
The way you hear a chord when you're singing alone
and only later realize the whole room was already full.
